title: List of Thai ingredients
data: Similar to the Chinese mee pok and lamian , it was not common in Thailand until in recent years as it is made from wheat which had to be imported . It is used stir-fried , deep-fried ( mi krop ) and in noodle soups

Fresh rice vermicelli made from fermented rice . It is commonly seen as a noodle to go with certain spicy soups and curries , but it is also popular with som tam and other Thai salads . Mon ( มอญ ) origin
The ultimate staple food for Thai people , so much that it can also mean food in general as in kin khao : to eat ( kin ) rice means the same as to eat food
ข้าวหอมมะลิ
Jasmine rice or Thai fragrant rice
This long-grained variety of rice , with its nutty aroma and a subtle pandan -like flavour , originates from Thailand and now forms the bulk of Thailand 's rice crop
ข้าวเหนียว
The main type of rice traditionally eaten in the northeast and north of Thailand . It is often served in a special bamboo container called a kratip khao
ข้าวเหนียวดำ
With a nutty taste , it can be mixed together with steamed white rice and eaten with savoury dishes or served sweetened with coconut milk
ก๋วยเตี๋ยว

The generic Thai word for rice noodles . The name comes from the Teochew dialect of Chinese , where the word kuai tiao literally means cake strips . In Chinese it only designates the wide variety which in Thai is called kuai tiao sen yai ( see shahe fen )
แป้งข้าวเจ้า
Used mainly in desserts and as a thickening agent
แป้งมันสำปะหลัง
Used mainly in desserts and as a thickening agent
Narrow , flat rice noodles ; used in such dishes as pad Thai and in noodle soups . Its full name would be kuai tiao sen lek
Similar to the Chinese rice vermicelli ; used in noodle soups . Its full name is kuai tiao sen mi
Wide , flat rice noodles , similar to the Chinese shahe fen ; used in dishes such as kuai tiao phat si-io and in noodle soups . Its full name is kuai tiao sen yai
Extremely thin noodles made from mung bean flour which turns transparent when moist . It can be used in salads and soups , or stir-fried
intro: This is a list of ingredients found in Thai cuisine.
